issue.title: Question about Deforming Boundaries and Remeshing with TMOP
issue.body:
Hi all,

I have a quick question.

My problem starts with a rectangular domain, but it must have highly deformed boundaries on the top and bottom surfaces, as well as deforming inner nodes over time (see attached image). So, I need to remesh my mesh continuously to run my model without blowing up.

However, to ensure the shape of my domain, I need to apply fixed boundary conditions for the TMOP method.

As a result, there may be unimproved elements near the top and bottom boundaries (see attached image).

I've heard that a boundary-fitting meshing (mesh-fitting app) approach can be useful for resolving my issue. However, the example you mentioned handles only the inner boundary using different material indicators.

In my case, the problem involves a single material and an arbitrary shape that is not determined analytically.

If you could provide me with any insights or solutions, it would be greatly appreciated.

Many thanks

Sungho


![Figure](https://github.com/mfem/mfem/assets/40257026/2e0d57ad-dc9d-40d9-aab6-607c17b239eb)

comment.body: Hi @sungho91, what should the boundary nodes do in this case? (knowing that the initial boundary normals are generally discontinuous across the elements).

I think having macros in MFEM headers is fine, however, I'd add a prefix `MFEM_` (`GKO_LEND` -> `MFEM_GKO_LEND`) since it is a macro defined by MFEM. Of course, removing the macro is also fine, if there is a preference for that approach -- I'm fine with either choice.

pull_request.title: Updates for newer Ginkgo versions and improvement to Ginkgo OpenMP use
pull_request.body:
This PR is a proposal to address #3909. 

There are changes to the use of `gko::lend` (deprecated) and the Ginkgo loggers, with compiler guards based on the version of Ginkgo being used. Hopefully all the deprecation warnings should be gone now. I built locally with Ginkgo 1.5 and 1.6 to test.

For Ginkgo's use of OpenMP, a small tester has been added in `config` to determine whether or not Ginkgo was built with OpenMP. I have tried to closely follow the way other testers are used (e.g., `get_hypre_version`) for both the CMake and Makefile builds, but please let me know if I've done something unacceptable to the build setup. 

For the default selection of Ginkgo executors, the proposed flow goes like this: 
| MFEM device type | Ginkgo Executor | Ginkgo Host Executor
|:-----------------|:-----------------:|:----------------:|
| CPU | OpenMP if Ginkgo has it *and* the MFEM device uses OpenMP; otherwise, Reference | N/A |
| CUDA | Cuda | OpenMP if Ginkgo has OpenMP, otherwise, Reference | 
| HIP   | Hip | OpenMP if Ginkgo has OpenMP, otherwise, Reference | 

I also added new constructors to `GinkgoExecutor`, allowing the user to explicitly set the host Executor instead of going with the default, e.g. if Ginkgo has OpenMP, but the user wants a `ReferenceExecutor` to pair with a `CudaExecutor`.

Closes #3909.

Closes #3909.

issue.title: Local Time Stepping
issue.body:
This issue has been raised earlier, but just wanted to know the current status of this. Has local time stepping been implemented in MFEM, or is it in the pipeline ? If in the pipeline or underdevelopment, can we contribute and when is it expected data that this could be available to the public ?

If it so happens, that there is no such implementation yet and it is not in the pipeline, can anyone be kind enough to suggest how this could be implemented ?

comment.body:
As discussed in the workshop let us start with what I have in my framework and [preprint on synchronous local time steping](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.07607.pdf). I hope that figure 2 summarizes the idea of the algorithm on a high level. Also note that I have not touched parallelization in the paper seriously because the design space is quite large.

Since I could not find good literature about this, I start with a summary of local time stepping for time-dependent ODEs: Semi-discretizing a time-dependent problem of the form $$\partial_t u = F(u,t)$$ with finite elements gives us the dofs $\tilde{u}$, a nonlinear operator $N$ and a mass matrix $M$ for the time dependent term, such that we obtain $$M d_t \tilde{u} = N(\tilde{u},t)$$. We can turn this problem into a pure ODE problem by inverting the mass matrix $$d_t \tilde{u} = M^{-1} N(\tilde{u},t) =: f(\tilde{u},t)$$. This can be also practically achieved by using DG discretizations (to obtain a block diagonal), but technically it is also possible to lump the mass matrix or use spectral elements. Anyways, the idea is that this allows us to investigate the problem as a pure ODE problem. Now we see that local time stepping is really just time discretization technique for ODEs. For ODEs is possible to assign different time step lengths to each single ODE in the system (in literature I usually find this named asynchronous local time stepping).
For context to the discussion which we had on zoom: A special case of this is what **I** call synchronous local time stepping (since I could not find a consistent naming in literature). Here where we define some global time interval length $\Delta t$ for a time interval of interest $[t_n, t_{n+1}]$. Now in the synchronous scheme we assign to each ODE some integer $N_i$, such that the local time step length is given by $\Delta t / 2^{N_i}$. This allows us to group the elements by their $N_i$ and hence possibly batched operations. Explicit local time stepping in these schemes generally works as variants of 
1. Choosing all ODEs $i$ for which the local predictor can be evaluated at its current local time $t^i$ and construct a prediction $\hat{u}_i$ for the next local time point (given some local time step length)
2. Choosing all ODEs $i$ with assigned current local time $t^i$ for which all $\hat{u}_j$ appearing in $f_i$ can be interpolated in time into the current stage of the time discretization (e.g. Runge-Kutta scheme), such that we can evaluate $f_i$ with some time interpolator for the $\hat{u}_j$
3. Goto 1 if there is any ODE whose local time is not at $_{n+1}$
Implicit local time stepping schemes on the other hand can be essentially seen as space-time fem with non-conforming time discretization.

Let us start with the algebraic perspective on this and structural properties coming from finite element discretizations. Note that I could not find any literature on this. DG schemes are a natural choice for local time stepping, because we can group the ODEs per element + the mass matrix is not super expensive to invert, but, as described above, nothing is stopping us to use other spatial discretization schemes, so I keep a very generic description for now.
I would describe local time stepping in a loop the following steps, where I denote the predictor function by $\hat{f}$ (which might come from a different operator $\hat{F} and the time interpolation operator by $T(\cdot, \cdot)$:
1. Build restriction operators $\hat{R}_v$ and $\hat{R}_p$ to extract the dofs where the predictor can be evaluated and their patches respectively
2. Update the predictor via $\hat{u}$ with the help of the right hand side $\hat{R}^T_v (\hat{R}_v\hat{f})(T(\hat{R}_p \tilde{u}, \hat{R}_p \hat{u})))$
3. Build restriction operators $R_v$ and $R_p$ to extract the dofs where the corrector can be evaluated and the associated patches respectively
4. Advance the solution $\tilde{u}$ with the help of the right hand side $R^T_v (R_v f)(T(R_p \tilde{u},  R_p \hat{u})))$

For higher order in time we might need to revisit how the interaction with the stages exactly works. I am also not sure under which conditions the operators coincide. Choosing the prolongation as the transpose should be correct in general. Also note that I have nowhere used any assumption regarding the spatial discretization yet. I think they "only" help us to efficiently construct the restrictions (without forming them explicitly).

cc @v-dobrev 
and @YohannDudouit : IIRC you helped me explaining LTS to Veselin on Zoom, so I would kindly ask you to take a look if this description is sound, since this is my very first try on writing down the class of schemes algebraically

issue.title: Updates for newer Ginkgo versions and improvement to Ginkgo OpenMP use
issue.body:
This PR is a proposal to address #3909. 

There are changes to the use of `gko::lend` (deprecated) and the Ginkgo loggers, with compiler guards based on the version of Ginkgo being used. Hopefully all the deprecation warnings should be gone now. I built locally with Ginkgo 1.5 and 1.6 to test.

For Ginkgo's use of OpenMP, a small tester has been added in `config` to determine whether or not Ginkgo was built with OpenMP. I have tried to closely follow the way other testers are used (e.g., `get_hypre_version`) for both the CMake and Makefile builds, but please let me know if I've done something unacceptable to the build setup. 

For the default selection of Ginkgo executors, the proposed flow goes like this: 
| MFEM device type | Ginkgo Executor | Ginkgo Host Executor
|:-----------------|:-----------------:|:----------------:|
| CPU | OpenMP if Ginkgo has it *and* the MFEM device uses OpenMP; otherwise, Reference | N/A |
| CUDA | Cuda | OpenMP if Ginkgo has OpenMP, otherwise, Reference | 
| HIP   | Hip | OpenMP if Ginkgo has OpenMP, otherwise, Reference | 

I also added new constructors to `GinkgoExecutor`, allowing the user to explicitly set the host Executor instead of going with the default, e.g. if Ginkgo has OpenMP, but the user wants a `ReferenceExecutor` to pair with a `CudaExecutor`.

Closes #3909.

pull_request.title: Fix ND elements p>=2 for Parallel Nonconforming meshes with triangular faces
pull_request.body:
This PR is an attempt to address the issue introduced by https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/1046 and marked with a failure in https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/2526. It reintroduces the ability to do simulations with nedelec elements of p>=2, on tetrahedra (and by extension increases support for wedge and pyramid elements).

The issue being that for NC meshes the definition of the ND face dofs were inconsistent across processor boundaries. The fix is achieved by modifying the Decode step by applying an additional Primal Transformation of the face DOF. This necessitates taking a "double step" through the passed message during decoding and processing pairs of dof together. The action of the 2x2 matrices on these rows of the P matrix is then achieved through the `AddRow` method.

This PR is also based on top of another fix for supporting face-edge constraints for tetrahedra https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/3587 but can be separated off more easily if that aids in review. 

To test this, ex3 and ex3p were modified with an additional `-nc` flag that allows for forcing tetrahedra meshes to be non-conforming. The results of 
```
./ex3 -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604422
mpirun -np 1 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 2 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 3 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
```
show that the results do not change with increasing numbers of processors. Plotting the solutions in glvis they appear indistinguishable. 

There was some additional refactoring of the DofTransformation class to make more use of inline methods, and also to mark the virtual methods in derived classes as final to aid in devirtualization. The pointer based methods are now virtual protected, whilst the type specific methods are exposed as public.

TODO

pull_request.title: Fix ND elements p>=2 for Parallel Nonconforming meshes with triangular faces
pull_request.body:
This PR is an attempt to address the issue introduced by https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/1046 and marked with a failure in https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/2526. It reintroduces the ability to do simulations with nedelec elements of p>=2, on tetrahedra (and by extension increases support for wedge and pyramid elements).

The issue being that for NC meshes the definition of the ND face dofs were inconsistent across processor boundaries. The fix is achieved by modifying the Decode step by applying an additional Primal Transformation of the face DOF. This necessitates taking a "double step" through the passed message during decoding and processing pairs of dof together. The action of the 2x2 matrices on these rows of the P matrix is then achieved through the `AddRow` method.

This PR is also based on top of another fix for supporting face-edge constraints for tetrahedra https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/3587 but can be separated off more easily if that aids in review. 

To test this, ex3 and ex3p were modified with an additional `-nc` flag that allows for forcing tetrahedra meshes to be non-conforming. The results of 
```
./ex3 -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604422
mpirun -np 1 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 2 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 3 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
```
show that the results do not change with increasing numbers of processors. Plotting the solutions in glvis they appear indistinguishable. 

There was some additional refactoring of the DofTransformation class to make more use of inline methods, and also to mark the virtual methods in derived classes as final to aid in devirtualization. The pointer based methods are now virtual protected, whilst the type specific methods are exposed as public.

TODO

pull_request.title: Fix ND elements p>=2 for Parallel Nonconforming meshes with triangular faces
pull_request.body:
This PR is an attempt to address the issue introduced by https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/1046 and marked with a failure in https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/2526. It reintroduces the ability to do simulations with nedelec elements of p>=2, on tetrahedra (and by extension increases support for wedge and pyramid elements).

The issue being that for NC meshes the definition of the ND face dofs were inconsistent across processor boundaries. The fix is achieved by modifying the Decode step by applying an additional Primal Transformation of the face DOF. This necessitates taking a "double step" through the passed message during decoding and processing pairs of dof together. The action of the 2x2 matrices on these rows of the P matrix is then achieved through the `AddRow` method.

This PR is also based on top of another fix for supporting face-edge constraints for tetrahedra https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/3587 but can be separated off more easily if that aids in review. 

To test this, ex3 and ex3p were modified with an additional `-nc` flag that allows for forcing tetrahedra meshes to be non-conforming. The results of 
```
./ex3 -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604422
mpirun -np 1 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 2 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 3 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
```
show that the results do not change with increasing numbers of processors. Plotting the solutions in glvis they appear indistinguishable. 

There was some additional refactoring of the DofTransformation class to make more use of inline methods, and also to mark the virtual methods in derived classes as final to aid in devirtualization. The pointer based methods are now virtual protected, whilst the type specific methods are exposed as public.

TODO

pull_request.title: Fix ND elements p>=2 for Parallel Nonconforming meshes with triangular faces
pull_request.body:
This PR is an attempt to address the issue introduced by https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/1046 and marked with a failure in https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/2526. It reintroduces the ability to do simulations with nedelec elements of p>=2, on tetrahedra (and by extension increases support for wedge and pyramid elements).

The issue being that for NC meshes the definition of the ND face dofs were inconsistent across processor boundaries. The fix is achieved by modifying the Decode step by applying an additional Primal Transformation of the face DOF. This necessitates taking a "double step" through the passed message during decoding and processing pairs of dof together. The action of the 2x2 matrices on these rows of the P matrix is then achieved through the `AddRow` method.

This PR is also based on top of another fix for supporting face-edge constraints for tetrahedra https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/3587 but can be separated off more easily if that aids in review. 

To test this, ex3 and ex3p were modified with an additional `-nc` flag that allows for forcing tetrahedra meshes to be non-conforming. The results of 
```
./ex3 -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604422
mpirun -np 1 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 2 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 3 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
```
show that the results do not change with increasing numbers of processors. Plotting the solutions in glvis they appear indistinguishable. 

There was some additional refactoring of the DofTransformation class to make more use of inline methods, and also to mark the virtual methods in derived classes as final to aid in devirtualization. The pointer based methods are now virtual protected, whilst the type specific methods are exposed as public.

show that the results do not change with increasing numbers of processors. Plotting the solutions in glvis they appear indistinguishable. 

There was some additional refactoring of the DofTransformation class to make more use of inline methods, and also to mark the virtual methods in derived classes as final to aid in devirtualization. The pointer based methods are now virtual protected, whilst the type specific methods are exposed as public.

pull_request.title: Fix ND elements p>=2 for Parallel Nonconforming meshes with triangular faces
pull_request.body:
This PR is an attempt to address the issue introduced by https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/1046 and marked with a failure in https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/2526. It reintroduces the ability to do simulations with nedelec elements of p>=2, on tetrahedra (and by extension increases support for wedge and pyramid elements).

The issue being that for NC meshes the definition of the ND face dofs were inconsistent across processor boundaries. The fix is achieved by modifying the Decode step by applying an additional Primal Transformation of the face DOF. This necessitates taking a "double step" through the passed message during decoding and processing pairs of dof together. The action of the 2x2 matrices on these rows of the P matrix is then achieved through the `AddRow` method.

This PR is also based on top of another fix for supporting face-edge constraints for tetrahedra https://github.com/mfem/mfem/pull/3587 but can be separated off more easily if that aids in review. 

To test this, ex3 and ex3p were modified with an additional `-nc` flag that allows for forcing tetrahedra meshes to be non-conforming. The results of 
```
./ex3 -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604422
mpirun -np 1 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 2 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
mpirun -np 3 ex3p -m ../data/inline-tet.mesh -o 2 -----> || E_h - E ||_{L^2} = 0.00604367
```
show that the results do not change with increasing numbers of processors. Plotting the solutions in glvis they appear indistinguishable. 

There was some additional refactoring of the DofTransformation class to make more use of inline methods, and also to mark the virtual methods in derived classes as final to aid in devirtualization. The pointer based methods are now virtual protected, whilst the type specific methods are exposed as public.

TODO
- [ ] Add test for prism/pyramid elements

issue.title: Implementing a cardiovascular outflow b.c.
issue.body:
Hello,

I am trying to apply the following boundary condition that is very common to cardiovascular flow modeling (resistance b.c.), where $\Gamma_a$ is a part of the boundary, $\mathbf{n}$ is the outward normal, $\mathbf{v}$ is the test function, $\mathbf{u}$ is the trial solution, and $R$ is some constant value.

$r(\mathbf{v},\mathbf{u}) = (\int_{\Gamma_a} \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{n} d\Gamma) * R * (\int_{\Gamma_a} \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{n} d\Gamma)$

and its discretization, let $S_{Ai} = \int_{\Gamma_a} N_A n_i d\Gamma$, then

$K_{ik}^{AB} = R*S_{Ai}*S_{Bk}$

where $N_A$ is the shape function corresponding to node $A$. To form this matrix, each node on the boundary $\Gamma_a$ needs to communicate with every other node on that boundary, so element by element formation of this matrix will not work.

My attempt at trying to form this matrix involves computing $S_{Ai}$ using `VectorBoundaryFluxLFIntegrator(1.0)` and `LinearForm->Assemble()` and then constructing a `SparseMatrix` by computing an outer product with the assembled linear form. However, I am struggling with how to do this in parallel? Is it possible to force the entire boundary of interest to exist on a single processor? Is there a better way to form this matrix in parallel?

My understanding is that I will need to form a  `HypreParMatrix` for this matrix to be able to use with my existing parallel code and data structures.

Thanks,
Ryan

comment.body:
Sure, here is a reference for this b.c

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0045782505002586
